posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
this thread’s not just gonna be a collection of FRs, but it’s mostly gonna be a collection of FRs.

so with the combined Discord news and the knowledge that more and more people use Signal for organising, i was thinking what direction Signal could and likely will go in to benefit those two groups of people.
obviously i don’t expect Signal to ever be a full Discord replacement (especially given that Discord is a machine that turns gamers into nitro subscribers), but i think there’s several ways Signal could become more welcoming to either group, some easier to implement and some harder.

inspired by this older article that’s been doing the rounds, i’m gonna propose three criteria to judge a FR by:

  1. it’s importance to online communities, that is to say larger groups of people who only somewhat know and trust each other, i.e. the exact communities that are now seeking a replacement for Discord. i have been quite vocal in my opinion about chatting with people you don’t trust, and while i still vehemently believe that statement is true, we’re gonna have to set it aside for the purpose of discussing the benefit to online communities, that necessarily don’t obey this assumption.
  2. it’s importance to organisers, that is to say people who do chat with people they trust but that do not engage in a regular chat, but rather are focused on specific purposes or goals. this can include stuff like political dissidents, to whom Signal has always been quite appealing, but also any other type of organiser. since i’m talking about organisers in general, i won’t be delving in this post into features that benefit people in free-speech-less countries, especially since most of these have already been implemented, though those are of course quite important.
  3. how easy i believe it will be to implement these given Signal’s current situation and the goals which are almost certain to remain unchanged. this means not just how complicated i believe a feature to be and how many changes to existing code will be involved, but also what security considerations come in to such a feature.

message history for new group members

importance to online communities: 4/5 — while the best way to preserve history is with a wiki or a forum, many communities still use chats for those purposes.
importance to organisers: 2/5 — mostly just in scenarios where more people are coming in and can’t be tl;dr’d to.
easy to implement: likely 1/5 — mostly on the security front, since having a single source for the entire message history means that data is untrustworthy, but having everyone resend the entire history on every join is highly impractical (and probably impossible for any former members). see more info in the original thread.

communities with subgroups

importance to online communities: 5/5 — pretty much the only way to separate different kinds of discussions to different chats while keeping the community cohesive
importance to organisers: 3/5 — very situational, can be an almost make or break for some and useless for others.
easy to implement: 3/5 depending on how it’s implemented — there’s some security considerations (do you share the group keys for all groups with every member of every single one of these groups?) but otherwise shouldn’t be too hard (the most barebone form of a community just has each group natively link to the rest and it’d still be quite good as an implementation).

ability for admins to delete messages for everyone

importance to online communities: 5/5 — the most basic of moderation tools after kicking a person out.
importance to organisers: 1/5 — you already mostly trust the people in the group. could be useful in highly situational scenarios.
easy to implement: probably 4/5 — basically just marrying the existing delete for everyone with the existing option to limit certain group capabilities to admins only. less security considerations (unless i’m missing something) and more, for lack of a better word, ethical considerations: should admins be given this capability? as you can see in the original thread, this is quite an active debate.

channels/broadcast lists

importance to online communities: 1/5 — channels don’t need to be any different to other types of groups other than only certain people being able to send a message, which is a feature that already exists.
importance to organisers: 4/5 — the main difference from online communities is that without a #​general chat, channels are likely to be by far the largest group in the collection of groups used (for those that use multiple groups, see previous paragraph), which could make it cumbersome.
easy to implement: 3/5 — depending on implementation, could possibly still be a regular group behind the scenes which makes things easier but has security considerations, could just be a list of people to DM all at once, which is easy to make but lacks clarity of being a channel to recipients, otherwise a more substantial change is required.

more granular group permissions (and other types of roles)

importance to online communities: 5/5 — very useful for moderation. same reason this very forum has trust levels.
importance to organisers: 1/5 — unless for some reason you don’t trust the people you’re chatting with, then you’re more similar to an online community.
easy to implement: 2/5 — mostly due to the large amount of option screens that will be required to make such options easily configurable, unless such roles come preconfigured, which would require some amount of imposition by Signal. might become easier with group labels, though we’ll have to wait and see.

automatic kickout of inactive pariticipants

importance to online communities: 3/5 — situational, but could be very important to those who need it. most online communities don’t kick inactive members though.
importance to organisers: 3/5 — situational again. many organising groups have a somewhat temporary nature to them anyway, so such a feature won’t be necessary to them. otherwise could be useful.
easiness to implement: 2/5 — since the server can’t look into groups (good), would require tracking on the client end how long since a member has last been active, then a kickout mechanism that works nicely if there’s more than one admin. requires lots of changes and prone to breaking.

live location sharing

importance to online communities: 1/5 — your interaction with these people is usually online only, you probably wouldn’t give them any location of yours, let alone a live one.
importance to organisers: 4/5 — somewhat situational but extremely useful when needed. not a 5/5 simply because in many situations the regular location sharing is less comfortable but still suffices.
easy to implement: 3/5 — several security and technical considerations. see original thread.

true threading

importance to online communities: 3/5 — i personally am in some communities where this is an absolute must-have, and others where it’s unnecessary. however, in most cases threading is actually better served by forum infrastructure, where the conversation is also more permanent.
importance to organisers: 2/5 — could be useful in highly specific instances, but otherwise cases where discussion must be split from an existing group and a new group wouldn’t suffice are quite rare.
easy to implement: 3/5 — lots of UI changes and some internal changes to messages. not too terrible, but also not that easy to do.

group custom member labels

importance to online communities: 4/5 — a proper role system more important.
importance to organisers: 2/5 — helps clarify offline roles, but can easily do without.
easy to implement: 5/5 — literally being developed as we speak and will likely land in beta in the not-too-distant future.

profile sharing controls

importance to online communities: 3/5 — mostly depends on what you put on your profile, otherwise better served by the following FR.
importance to organisers: 3/5 — really only important in cases dealing with the law, otherwise again better served by the following FR and by true broadcast lists.
easy to implement: 2/5 — involves many moving parts, and any such change will have to be watertight when it comes to security.

multiple identities/identity per group

importance to online communities: 4/5 — mostly due to the same reasons as custom labels.
importance to organisers: 3/5 — again, sits somewhere inbetween profile sharing controls and labels.
easy to implement: 4/5 if superficial only — will likely work similarly to labels. 2/5 if involves profile sharing controls.

mention everyone in the group

importance to online communities: 4/5 — has kinda become the norm in chat communities.
importance to organisers: 4/5 — a way to separate an important announcement from otherwise regular discussion without needing a separate broadcast option.
easy to implement: probably 4/5 — assuming custom labels include mentioning, mostly because there’s a need to also add controls over this functionality. if they do not, 3/5 since this will need to be implemented from nothing.

mention admins

importance to online communities: 5/5 — important moderation tool.
importance to organisers 1/5 — same reason as “more granular permissions”. you already trust your fellow members more, plus there aren’t likely gonna be that many admins.
easy to implement 4/5 or 3/5 — same as mentioning everyone.

bot support

importance to online communities: 4/5 — very useful for communities that use auto-moderation, otherwise nice-to-have.
importance to organisers: 1/5 — unlikely to ever come up.
easy to implement: 1/5 (or, depending on your perspective, 5/5) — a one that’s a bit weird to rank, since in some sense bot support already exists in Signal, you just need an appropriate client. and such clients exist, and Signal bots already exist (i personally have already encountered one). however, when it comes to the question of an official bot support, it’s not just a question of is this easy to do, but more is it likely to happen, the answer to which is probably no, because since the server can’t inspect groups and chats (good), this has high spam implications.

feel free to suggest (and similarly rank!) any more improvements and changes that you think could be relevant to Signal better supporting either of these types of users. let’s not discuss the merits of each request here though, use the existing threads for that, or if you came up with a new feature request, create a new feature request.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i want to mention that i found out about the most recent Soatok blog while i was writing this very long post:

Signal media coverage — articles & news General Discussion
Soatok Mentions Signal and its cons as a Discord replacement. But also says: Currently, the only messaging app I’ve evaluated that actually meets the bar for privacy (i.e., end-to-end encryption) is, unfortunately, Signal.

i didn’t stop to read it since that post is evaluating the existing situation while i talk about the future, so i didn’t think there’d be much overlap. if i encounter stuff there that’s relevant here though, i’ll mention it.

Good summary for this topic.
I was thinking about this and maybe current groups and public “community” ones should be handled separately (if devs deceide they want to implement the former).

Separate type of groups, separate type of rules, separate kind of member handling.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: i think pretty much anything a Discord-esque large community can benefit from a public group can benefit from and vice versa. in fact i kinda treat them interchangeably in this thread for that reason.

Great list!

For me, subgroups is the big one. Groups that use this elsewhere could then move over without much friction.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i do wanna mention, having a community with subgroups isn’t actually that hard even with existing features. i’m in one that spans 20 chats using only a text document to coordinate between them.
(that’s not to say i’m not in favour of the feature. i am. just putting things into perspective.)
Now that pinned chats are a thing, you could have an organizer pin a chat that maps the subgroups

posts.name: diffrentcolours
posts.cooked: Pretty much all the bug reports / FRs I’ve posted here have been coming from actual organisers on the ground fighting against ICE. Admins deleting messages is a key feature for them, as right-wing chuds will always find some way to infiltrate, and have been spamming organiser chats with CSAM and gore images.

jerryasu:

Now that pinned chats are a thing, you could have an organizer pin a chat that maps the subgroups

This is not a good solution because any new members joining won’t see this pinned message (because it was posted before they joined).
Oh. Seems like maybe pinned chats should be persistent the way the group description is. Or maybe the group info needs to not have a limit on how long it is

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
persistent pinned message is basically a mini version of message history, with all the issues.
changing the group description length is the way to go:

Expand the group chat description (or, pin posts!) Feature Requests
Hi there, Grateful for Signal in these less-secure times. I’m trying to move some chats from Whats App to Signal, and am frustrated with the limited character allowance for “group description.” Can you increase the allowance to up to 2-3K characters for those of us trying to establish group norms in a chat (with ongoing new members added)? Or, allow the ability to pin a post in a group chat that all members (even if added later) can see? It is annoying to repost a GROUP RULES post over and …
Improve Group Descriptions Android UI/UX
480 glyphs, but it also must fit in 8192 bytes when encrypted (the code below is for Signal iOS, but the numbers are the same on Android). To get a feel for what a “glyph” is, you can take a look at this test.
